reasoning: The critique targets a real load-bearing step in §3.3: the move from “bounded (universe-wide) concave value” to “approximately linear in practice” via the premise that humanity’s marginal impact is tiny because there is vast independent value elsewhere (aliens/infinite background). If that step fails, a nontrivial class of bounded views could remain genuinely nonlinear over the relevant range, weakening the paper’s attempt to show that most bounded views are fussy. However, it doesn’t threaten the whole position: the essay also argues for fussiness via (i) eutopian fragility/multiplicative factors and (ii) unbounded/linear and other bounded constructions, so at most a moderate fraction of the overall case is undermined (centrality ~0.33). The objection is conceptually strong as a conditional: if the universe is largely value-empty absent our expansion, or if advanced life is rare, the ‘tiny marginal change’ assumption can break. But it is more a vulnerability/contingency point than a demonstration that the authors’ cosmological premise is actually false or unlikely, and the authors already hedge with probabilistic language; thus it only partially weakens the targeted step (strength ~0.45). Most claims in the critique are correct and relevant, though it somewhat overstates how much the classification ‘breaks’ (the authors still have other arguments for bounded-view fussiness even if this particular collapse-to-linearity argument weakens). Clear, tightly focused, with little fluff.
title: The "alien universe" assumption lacks empirical grounding.
